title: Jimmy Carter, former president of the United States, has died at 100
summary: The 39th American president, a man with deep humanist convictions, died peacefully in his sleep on Sunday at his Georgia home, The Carter Center announced. Carter was awarded the 2002 Nobel Peace Prize for his work to find peaceful solutions to international conflicts.

title: Airplane crashes while landing in South Korea, killing 179
summary: Footage of the crash aired by YTN television showed the Jeju Air plane skidding across the airstrip and colliding head-on with a concrete wall on the outskirts of the facility.

title: Netanyahu 'in good condition' after prostate surgery, hospital says
summary: The Israeli prime minister 'will remain under observation' in the recovery unit, Hadassah Medical Centre said in a statement on Sunday following the procedure. On Saturday, Netanyahu's office announced that he had been diagnosed with a urinary tract infection caused by a benign prostate enlargement.

title: Kavelashvili sworn in as Georgia's president as thousands protest against pro-Russian leader
summary: The inauguration of former football player Kavelashvili is set to further escalate a months-long political crisis that has seen huge pro-European Union demonstrations.

title: In Georgia, a prince of words and barricades
summary: All his life, poet Kote Kubaneishvili has fought for freedom. Every evening in Tbilisi, the 70-something joins thousands of his fellow citizens in protesting against the December 14 election of pro-Russian President Mikheil Kavelashvili.

title: The best TV shows of 2024, according to Le Monde's critics
summary: From 'La Mesias' to 'The Diplomat,' 'Say Nothing' to 'Latecomers,' and let's not forget 'Hippocrate,' 'Shōgun' and 'Disclaimer': Here's a list of the best TV shows journalists Audrey Fournier and Thomas Sotinel watched this year.

title: With Javier Milei, a year of chainsaws and controlled inflation in Argentina
summary: The ultraliberal president, who took office in December 2023, had made the tool a symbol of his anti-public spending campaign. He has kept his promise by cutting back on government spending and is delighted with inflation going down to 2.4% in November from 25.5% a year earlier.

title: Croatia's president wins election, exit poll shows
summary: President Zoran Milanovic, in the first round, won 51.48% of the vote, while Dragan Primorac, the candidate of the ruling conservative HDZ party, came second with 19.29%. The election comes as the European Union and NATO member country of 3.8 million people struggle with biting inflation, widespread corruption and a labor shortage.

title: 'Le Soulier de satin' exalts the Comédie-Française
summary: Eric Ruf directs Claudel's play with sensuality, performed by some 20 actors assuming a myriad of parts.

title: From Bottega Veneta to Chanel, fashion reshuffles top talents amid economic storm
summary: Matthieu Blazy's appointment as Chanel's artistic director on December 12 ended the suspense that had the fashion world holding its breath. It was the high point of a transfer market that had been shaking up luxury fashion houses for months. This frantic waltz of designers reflects the difficulties of a sector faced with a significant drop in sales.

title: Azerbaijan accuses Russia of trying to hide causes of plane crash
summary: Ilham Aliyev said the jet that crashed this week, killing 38 of the 67 people onboard, was hit 'by accident' by Russia. On Saturday, Russian President Vladimir Putin apologized for the crash but stopped short of accepting that it might have been hit by Russian fire.

title: How the United Arab Emirates has embraced ice hockey culture
summary: For the last 15 years, the petromonarchy, encouraged in particular by Russian expatriates, has seen ice hockey and curling being developed and structured into national sports, with seven ice hockey teams participating in the national championships

title: Israeli Ministry of Health report documents violence endured by hostages in Gaza
summary: Hostage testimonies detail detention conditions in the Gaza Strip following their abductions on October 7, during the Hamas attack on Israel. The report, which describes beatings, burns and sexual assault, is due to be submitted to the UN.

title: Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama is pulling out all the stops to speed up his country's accession to the EU
summary: The leader has claimed that Albania, which began negotiations with Brussels in mid-October, will be ready to join the European Union in 2028, despite concerns about its powerful mafia.

title: Friedrich Merz, a hardline, arrogant conservative-liberal, eyes Germany's chancellery
summary: The Christian Democrat – who will represent the CDU-CSU in the federal elections on February 23, 2025 – is strongly positioned to become Germany's next chancellor, according to polls.

title: French pastry chefs express their creativity from New York to Tulum
summary: In a dreamy Mexican hotel, Antonin Simon has adapted his recipes to local taste buds. In the US, Eunji Lee is offering sweets that blend her French, Korean and New York cultures. And Yann Couvreur has exported his Parisian classics to stores in Seoul, Riyadh and Dubai.

title: In search of the bacteria capable of eating forever chemicals
summary: At the crossroads of chemistry, biology, physics and engineering, a Strasbourg-based team is examining contaminated soil samples in an attempt to identify a micro-organism that has adapted to PFAS and may have developed enzymes capable of degrading them.

title: Romania's response to election manipulation is a lesson for democracies
summary: By canceling the second round of the presidential election, the Constitutional Court highlighted the importance of addressing voter manipulation on TikTok in favor of a far-right candidate.

title: Pakistan faces unprecedented resurgence of Taliban violence
summary: The Taliban’s return to Afghanistan in 2021 has fueled a surge in deadly attacks by the Pakistani Taliban, with 2024 now the deadliest year on record.

title: New York from the window of a taxi cab
summary: To pay for his photography studies, Joseph Rodríguez criss-crossed his city at the wheel of a rented 'cab' from 1977 to 1987. From his vehicle, he captured street scenes and portrayed his passengers: partygoers leaving nightclubs or small families in their Sunday best. The Fotomuseum in Maastricht, the Netherlands, is devoting a retrospective to the career of the 73-year-old documentary photographer.

title: Fish and chips and picturesque villages: Welcome to 'Franglo-Saxon' France
summary: Almost five years after Brexit, British nationals are still moving to France in large numbers. In some rural areas, they are stemming demographic hemorrhage and helping to revitalize the local economy and cultural life.

title: Pelicot rape trial: Ex-husband Dominique Pelicot will not appeal
summary: Dominique Pelicot, the main defendant among 51 men convicted in a mass rape trial, will not appeal his 20-year prison sentence for having drugged and raped his then-wife and soliciting many other men to do the same, according to his lawyer.

title: Mayotte: French premier Bayrou promises concrete aid for cyclone-struck island
summary: Arriving in the French overseas department, which suffered the ravages of Cyclone Chido, the most devastating disaster to hit the Indian Ocean island in 90 years, Prime Minister Francois Bayrou announced both short- and long-term plans for Mayotte.

title: Camille Fourmont, La Buvette's visionary restaurateur in eastern Paris
summary: In just a few years, this self-taught talent has become a leading figure in the bistronomy scene in eastern Paris, with her wine bar. Fourmont, who recently opened another spot for cheese lovers, is also a decorator, culinary identity creator and ceramicist in her spare time.

title: Jeju Air plane crash: Shock and uncertainty in South Korea after country's worst air disaster
summary: The crash of flight 2216 from Bangkok, on Sunday, December 29, left 179 people dead and two injured at Muan airport. A bird strike has been presumed as the cause of the accident, but many questions remain.

title: Jimmy Carter was a tireless fighter against disease and for women's rights
summary: At the end of his term of office, the former US president launched the Carter Center in 1982, a foundation with far-reaching philanthropic ambitions. He died on December 29, aged 100.

title: Syria's new leader al-Sharaa insists on taking time for 'national dialogue' before elections
summary: In his first interview with an Arab media outlet, Ahmed al-Sharaa, the head of the armed group HTS said it would be four years before elections were held in Syria. He also reached out to Iran and Russia, the former allies of ex-dictator Bashar al-Assad.
